channel.title: Federal Election Interference Risk Map
channel.description: Tracking DOJ lawsuits, FBI actions, and Project 2025 implementation across all 50 US states ahead of the 2026 midterms.

item.title: House passes SAVE America Act 218-213, first GOP senator opposes
item.description: The House voted 218-213 on Feb 11 to pass the SAVE America Act, an expanded version of the SAVE Act that requires proof of citizenship to register to vote, photo ID to cast a ballot, and monthly voter roll purges using DHS databases. All Republicans present voted yes; Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-TX) was the sole Democratic yes vote. Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) became the first Republican senator to oppose, warning it federalizes elections — the same argument the GOP used against Democrats in 2021. The bill faces a 60-vote threshold in the Senate, where Majority Leader Thune says there are "not even close" to votes to eliminate the filibuster.

item.title: Nebraska court dismisses lawsuit blocking voter data transfer to DOJ
item.description: A Lancaster County judge dismissed Common Cause Nebraska's lawsuit attempting to block the transfer of voter data to the DOJ. The judge ruled on standing grounds, not the merits. Common Cause is appealing to the Nebraska Court of Appeals, but Secretary of State Evnen plans to proceed with the data transfer on Feb 12, 2026.

item.title: Trump-appointed judge dismisses Michigan voter data lawsuit
item.description: U.S. District Judge Hala Jarbou, a Trump appointee, dismissed the DOJ's lawsuit seeking Michigan's voter rolls. She ruled that none of the three federal laws cited — the Civil Rights Act of 1960, NVRA, and HAVA — require states to hand over the data. This is the third dismissal on the merits, after California and Oregon. The DOJ is now 0-for-3 in court.

item.title: Trump calls on Republicans to "nationalize the voting"
item.description: President Trump told conservative podcaster Dan Bongino that Republicans should "take over the voting in at least 15 places" and "nationalize the voting." The next day he doubled down, saying "I don't know why the federal government doesn't do them anyway." The Constitution explicitly delegates election administration to the states. Election experts called it an alarming escalation.

item.title: AG Bondi demands Minnesota voter rolls as condition for pulling ICE
item.description: Attorney General Pam Bondi sent a letter to Minnesota Governor Tim Walz demanding voter rolls and welfare data as conditions for withdrawing ICE from Minneapolis — hours after federal agents fatally shot a second person in the city. Minnesota Secretary of State Steve Simon called it "an apparent ransom to pay for our state's peace and security." Arizona's Secretary of State compared it to "organized crime."

item.title: Virginia becomes 24th state sued by DOJ for voter data
item.description: The Department of Justice has sued Virginia for voter registration data, making it the 24th state to face legal action over refusal to hand over sensitive voter information including Social Security numbers.

item.title: FBI raids Fulton County, Georgia election offices
item.description: The FBI raided Fulton County election offices on January 28, seizing 2020 ballots and voter rolls. DNI Tulsi Gabbard was on-site and reportedly called President Trump during the raid. This represents the first direct federal law enforcement action against state election infrastructure.

item.title: Federal judge dismisses Georgia voter data lawsuit on jurisdictional grounds
item.description: A federal judge dismissed the DOJ's voter data lawsuit against Georgia because the government filed in the wrong court (Macon instead of Atlanta). The case was dismissed without prejudice, meaning DOJ can refile. Unlike the California and Oregon dismissals, this was not a ruling on the merits of DOJ's legal theory.

item.title: Courts dismiss California and Oregon voter data cases
item.description: Federal courts dismissed the DOJ's voter data lawsuits against both California and Oregon. The California judge found "an alarming picture regarding the centralization of Americans' information within the Executive Branch."

item.title: DOJ files second wave of voter data lawsuits
item.description: The Department of Justice sued Wisconsin, Illinois, Georgia, Washington D.C., Delaware, Maryland, New Mexico, Rhode Island, Vermont, Washington state, and others in a second wave of lawsuits demanding voter registration data including sensitive personal information.

item.title: DOJ sues first wave of states for voter data
item.description: The Department of Justice sued California, Michigan, Minnesota, New Hampshire, New York, Oregon, and Pennsylvania for refusing to hand over complete voter registration files including driver's license numbers and partial Social Security numbers.

item.title: CISA gutted — 1,000+ election security staff lost
item.description: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency has lost over 1,000 employees through firings, layoffs, and transfers. CISA had helped local election officials protect voting systems from hacking. Dismantling CISA was a key Project 2025 recommendation.
